I think the tapered ones accelerate faster because there is less material to accelerate. You would assume that having more potential energy throughout the whole band would work the best, but that's not how it works at all. Let's imagine the rubber band at the molecular level. If you stretched out a rubber band and were able to let go of both ends simultaneously, all the elastic energy contracting the molecules together would result in a net force towards the middle of the band, which is where it would contract to. In a slingshot, this is the natural tendency, but it's not a plain rubber band. There it a fixed point in this situation (the handle) which changes everything. Since the molecules at the fixed point can't move anywhere, they simply pull on the one's next to each other, which pull on the ones next to them, all the way down to the end, which are the only molecules able to move. Because of this linked relationship between the molecules, the acceleration of the end is almost entirely dependent on the contraction of the whole rest of the band, so it doesn't really matter how strongly the end can contract. This means that having a strong but bulky band the entire length is useless, and just adds extra weight for the whole rest of the band to accelerate once the end is done contracting. Having a tapered end means less useless weight and thus is much more efficient. Plus it probably reduces air resistance as a little bonus.


I know the whole band is actually contracting simultaneously as opposed to 1 molecule at a time, but the logic doesn't really change, it's just easier to explain it that way.


It's kinda like a whip: you can't get the end to go that fast unless you change the ratio of speed and mass in the initial momentum of the big end of the whip. In the same way, you can't get the ball to go that fast unless you change the ratio of the elasticity and mass of the band.

Others mentioned visco-elastic materials, but I don't think that's the issue. It's because of entropy!

Most materials elongate as they warm and shorten as they cool, but rubber works the other way around. The elastic material is a bunch of long tangled molecules. When you pull the band to stretch it, you do work on the material. A perfectly Hookean material would retain that work via interatomic forces and changes in interatomic spacing. The rubber, though, also has these tangled molecules line up and become less jumbled. Thus, entropy drops. If entropy drops, then the system needs to get rid of T*dS worth of heat. This is why the band warms when stretched. You want to have that heat available to help return to a shortened, tangled state. Otherwise, you need to rob some energy from the stored elastic energy, which then is not available for propelling the ball.

So, I don't think this is visco-elasticity. I think it's thermodynamics and the weirdness of rubber because it is dominated by entropy, contrary to most materials.

If you don't believe me about rubber being odd, cut a rubber band to make it into a strip, hang a weight from it, and warm it gently with a heat source. You will easily see it shorten by a significant amount, which is exactly the opposite of what most materials do.

I think, when the rubber band cools down it's molecules get in a more stable arrangement/solid-like state, which has to be "broken" again by heating these molecules again in order to fulfill the potential energy. So a part of the potential energy goes into "reheating" the molecules to the temperature at which they are moving the easiest.

And I think the thicker vs. thinner band is not a general thing, it depends how much mass it has to move. I think, in a vacuum thinner elastic materials would always move faster as they have to overcome less of their own molecular resistance.
While the theoretical "speed" in one specific material is the same for all thicknesses (ignoring it's own friction and mass), what changes is the force it carries. So every specitic thickness of rubber band has a sweet spot for a specific amount of mass to shoot. Where the rubber band-thickness vs rubber band-weight graph would overlap would be the minimum optimal thickness the rubber band must have. The steel ball weight in this video simply is closer to the sweetspot of the thinner band than the sweetspot of the thicker band, therefore the additional band only causes more friction.

Heat energy is 'wasted' (I.e. it arises due to inefficiency and 'leaks' out of the rubber into the surroundings.

As you stretch the rubber, you 'stretch' the bonds holding it together. The bonds 'want' to reduce their energy but are unable to 'unstretch' themselves, so heat is released (this is why the band feels warm to the touch).

When the band is released, the potential (stretchy) energy is converted to kinetic energy and the band cools as it does work to move the projectile.

I know I'm super late to the party but this is the first time I've seen this video. The first question is pretty easy, it's all comes down to energy. When the band is drawn back, your are inputting a bunch of energy in the form of work and heat. If you release immediately very little energy will be lost because as the band contracts it cools and converts the heat back into spring potential energy. If instead you allow the band to cool before release, it will lose all of that energy and upon contraction (and cooling) will pull the back from the spring potential.

TLDR if you let it cool you loose the heat energy, if you don't, the energy remains in the system.

Destin, I think to truly answer this question you need to do some more testing with different elastic profiles. You might notice if you stretch an un-tapered piece of elastic the extreme ends will stretch more than the middle. This makes sense because the middle of the piece of elastic is connected to the force by more lossy elastic.
So, if we stretch this elastic the extreme ends are storing more potential energy than the middle section. We can adjust this by changing the taper of the elastic so that more is used to it’s maximum energy storage potential. Presumably the taper you tested is better in this regard than a non-tapered piece.

Rubber is a tangled web of molecules which can be thought of as mobile chains. Each one is acting as a random coil due to thermal motion, however there is a preferred length that the chains want to be at, as this length can be obtained for the largest range of combinations of relative bond orientations. This is the group of chains maximising their entropy. As temperature increases, the preference for this equilibrium length increases as the multiplicity of this macrostate increases (giving the increased potential energy of displacement with temperature). As the rubber is stretched, the chains lengthen, which would lead to a decrease in entropy. The energy associated with the change is released as thermal energy in order to keep the total universe entropy >=0 (hence the band heating on stretching).

Here is the answer to both of your questions form a PhD in Mechanical Engineering:

Why holding the rubber band reduces efficiency? Ans: Once you hold the rubber band , since its material partly behaves as viscoelastic , the stress in the band gradually drops, hence reduces Max force initially generated by stretching, which finally causing a drop in kinetic energy of the ball. That dissipated energy appears as heat. i.e part of initial elastic energy dissipates as heat when you hesitate unless you release it immediately!

Why tapered band ( less material) is more effective than untapered ? Ans: it’s a bit tricky. Note that all elastic energy in the rubber releases as kinetic energy in the ball PLUS kinetic energy in the rubber band. Yes ! don’t forget rubber band also obtains kinetic energy because of its mass when it pushes the ball forward. The more mass in the band, the less kinetic energy left for the ball ! Mathematically, a third of mass in the rubber band comes into account. Therefore, reducing the mass of rubber band ( by tapering) will increase the share of kinetic energy of the ball at the end. However, the tapered may loose a bit elastic energy but ratio wise, because the Hook's law is non linear for the rubber band, the net effect is in favor to increase the ball kinetic energy .

The confusion about the relationship between a rubber band's elasticity and its temperature comes from the misconception that, when an elastomer such as rubber is stretched, the work done to stretch the band is stored as potential energy in strained chemical bonds within the rubber. This is in fact not true. While surely some of the work done to stretch the band is stored as potential energy, most of it is immediately dissipated as heat. Heat is then absorbed from the surroundings as the band goes from a stretched state to an un-stretched state. The reason for this is pretty interesting, in my opinion. Rubber is made of polymers, or long chainlike molecules. When rubber is in the un-stretched state, you can imagine them tangled up like spaghetti, except Brownian motion causes all of the spaghetti strands to wiggle around each other. They have a bit of room to wiggle around, because rubber is an amorphous solid and has no lattice structure, but they can't just move anywhere; they're still constrained by the chemical interactions which maintain the material's shape. When you stretch the rubber band, you are pulling those spaghetti strands apart a little bit, but they never slide past each other like in a fluid. The chemical bonds holding the material together aren't strained very much until the rubber is stretched almost to the point of breaking. In a stretched stat, the Brownian motion of the polymers that make up the rubber is constrained much more tightly by chemical bonds. The number of microstates associated with the un-stretched system is greater than the number of microstates associated with the stretched system, because the Brownian motion of the molecules is constrained more and more as the rubber is stretches. This means that the entropy of the un-stretched state is higher. We see the rubber lose elasticity as it cools down because the polymers are moving less, which means that there are fewer microstates when it returns to the un-stretched stat, and there is therefore a smaller entropy difference between states. This is interesting because it means that the reason for the rubber band's contraction is not entirely because of the first law of thermodynamics (energy is conserved), but in fact is mostly due to the second law (entropy always increases). At first glance everyone always assumes it's a first law process.

The loss of tension in the rubber band while keeping at a fixed stretched is due to Viscoelastic relaxation..... Rubber is a polymer, and it behaves both as a solid and as a liquid at the same time.... a part of it behaves like an elastic solid (follows hooks law, force / stress linearly proportional to deformation / strain), whereas the rest of the material behaves like a liquid (follows newton's law of viscosity, force is proportional to velocity, or deformation rate).....

So, when you stretch the rubber band, you induce an elastic deformation in the solid part as well as a viscous flow in the liquid part. Now, as you hold the band at a fixed stretched position: you need to provide the force to maintain the elastic deformation, but as you no longer maintaining the flow in the liquid part (rate of deformation, i.e. velocity or 'flow-rate' is zero); so that part of the force disappears as the liquid settles down with time. At a molecular level, there are structural relaxation that dictates all of it.The heat that you are referring to generates when you stretch the rubber, as we tend to expand the rubber adiabatically (extremely fast), and this heat dissipates in the environment to achieve a thermal equilibrium. This will probably have no significant impact on the dynamics of the 'bullet' (or whatever is the appropriate terminology).

Interestingly, if you do the same rubber stretching versus force experiment once again with different rate of deformation (strain-rate) you will see, it is not only the amount of deformation that determines the necessary load, but also the rate of deformation (which is never a case for elastic solid).... higher rate of deformation will need to overcome more viscous force.

It is the gradient of the tension in the bands that gives the system more order, and therefore less energy is wasted. In the tapered bands, the thicker part near the front starts to contract more quickly than the thinner end, as you can observe if you go frame by frame at 4:44 while pausing at each frame. This lets the thick part to relax almost completely at the end of the acceleration period while the thinnest length still applies force, thereby allowing the pouch to follow the projectile through the Y, allowing the bands to transfer some of their kinetic energy to the projectile with a whipping effect. All parts of the uniform bands pull at the same time and then ripple at the same time. This makes the bands curve out, increasing the angle of tension toward the end, and then then the pouch releases the projectile too soon and then flips over the fork with all of its kinetic energy wasted. The lower weight of the tapered bands plus the strain (like he explains in the video) probably both contribute to the initial increase in acceleration, but I believe it is the order of the system which makes it better overall.

As for the tapered elastic: The parts of the elastic closer to the yoke don't only have to accelerate only the ball, but also the parts of elastic closer to the ball. the closer to the ball you come, the less of that is required. Evening out that workload via adapted cross sections also ensures that more or less all parts of the elastic get slack at the same time.

The loss of tension when rubber is held stretched is not due to heat loss, but due to what is known as elastic-plastic or visco-elastic behavior. Elastomeres and thermoplastics behave as if they were very viscous fluids. So you have to release immediately in order to not flow it too long. Jürg (?) rightly calls that hysteresis. It's the energy lost inside the hysteresis curve when a material is repeatedly stretched and released. The energy loss causes what is known as hysteresis heating in the elastic material.

I'm guessing Destin already knows this, and maybe it is somewhere in the 800 comments I didn't read, but here goes :D

It's easier to explain with gasses.
When you compress a gas, you also compress all the heat(energy) it has into a smaller space, so the gas get's hotter.
Or on a molecular level: The atoms/molecules in the gas get closer to each other and therefore hit each other more often - thus releasing more energy witch get's to the edge of the container, then to the air outside. So the gas cools.
Now, in order for the gas to expand again, you need to give it the same energy it had before it was compressed.
Deodorant - it is a gas in a can that is under pressure and at room temperature. When it was compressed into the can, it got hot, and then slowly cooled off. When you spray the deodorant, the gas absorbs any heat it can find in order to get enough energy to expand(that is why you can freeze your skin if you spray deodorant directly on it).
(or the can will blow up when you heat it as the gas expands inside the can increasing pressure)

On to rubber(finally)
Same principle(despite what you may think).
When you stretch rubber, the atoms in the rubber get closer to each other resulting in more bumping into each other - heat. When you release the rubber, the atoms/molecules absorb the heat again to return to their previous state.
And rubber is not gas! This is important because the sling shot happens faster than the rubber molecules can take heat from the air and regain their energy. While gas molecules just keep on spreading trough the air looking for heat, the rubber is left only with the heat(aka energy) in it's container - the band.

The tapered band question...well...I can take a shot at it:
When you stretch rubber, you give it energy. The energy(potential until it's released)
is distributed evenly throughout the rubber.
On a sling shot:
A straight rubber band is pulled to a length and energy is distributed evenly throughout the band. when you release, the energy is equally 'consumed' by the whole rubber. And with some math you can calculate stuff :)
But a tapered band is narrower in one place. When you pull the end of the band, the tapered(narrow) part stretches first, because it requires less energy to do so. Then the cascade begins.
As you pull the band(imagine this) the tapered part get's(let's just say) hotter, and the rubber molecules in it start moving fast. Now as you keep pulling, the atoms in the tapered part start moving faster and faster, hitting the outer 'layers' of rubber atoms and giving them energy.
So the 'source' of energy distribution is the tapered part, and it's giving maximum energy output to surrounding rubber - thus maximum potential energy in the rubber closer to the tapered part.
While the straight band get's the force evenly distributed, and has 'medium' energy the entire length of the band - the tapered band has 'maximum' energy in one part then the rest of the band. But, that is more potential energy.
If you were to just keep pulling, eventually both bands would reach the same amount of potential energy, as the narrow part on the tapered band achieves it's maximum first.

My answer to question 2:

The static part:
Tapering the bands decreases the mass to be accelerated without losing much of the draw weight: the thinner end is stressed more but elongates less than proportionately (as seen on the curved stress-strain graph), so the thicker end is closer to its untapered-case-elongation than a Hookean spring would be.

The kinetic part:
I guess that a small amount of rubber under high strain loses less heat due to hysteresis than a large amount under low strain.

My answer to question 1:

In the stretched rubber, the elastomers align and get closer over time, and the entropy decreases while heat is dissipated into the surroundings. During the shot (contraction), the rubber's heat is converted into entropy and electrostatic PE as the molecules curl up again and each one takes up more space: the rubber cools. It then regains the same heat from the surroundings that it lost in the stretched state - therefore the stretched state is to be avoided.

Answer to First question. (Laymans terms and thoughts, I'm no expert)
When the bands are pulled, they have an elastic force that drives them back to their original unstretched form/position.

By shooting straight away, you're keeping the band from permanently stretching.

Using simple laws of energy conservation. 

PE of a "spring" = KE of a projectile =>

0.5k*x^2=0.5m*v^2  ==  k*x^2=m*v^2 
rearranged that is v=sqrt(k/m)*x

v=v0+x*a and v0=0  =>  v=x*a => 

a=sqrt(k/m) 

(PE potential energy, KE kinetic energy, x displacement, m mass, k spring constant, v velocity, a acceleration)

Now if our m is already small compared to k & m is decreased by removing mass while k is increased because of the above factors our acceleration will be increased dramatically.

The heat present in the band is not produced by a kinetic energy transform, it is a product of individual polymers within the rubber untangling & bonds with its neighbors breaking. A material under stress always experiences creep. Creep decreases resistance to stress, increases relative elongation / unit of stress (strain) and is directly related to time and heat. By heating the rubber with the pull, introducing creep, the rubber breaks down and loses elasticity, even if only fractionally.

For question #1: Rubber bands are polymers.  At the molecular level, the polymers are long strings that randomly coil into spheres.  Straining the rubber band along one axis stretches the spheres into ellipsoids, which is not energetically favorable.  Even though it's a solid, these polymer molecules have a limited ability to move.  Given some time, the polymers will randomly move to relieve some of the strain, and that results in a loss in some elastic force.

My only contribution is that the kinetic energy contained in the band itself (at the time the band stops accelerating the projectile)  will be less for the tapered band, since the part of the band that is moving the fastest is significantly less massive.  I ran the integral for a linear spring throwing a projectile many years ago, and I forget the results, but there's a factor of 1/6 in there that was unexpected.  So this effect would be minimized with a heavier projectile, of course.

From a chemist's perspective I'm not sure that ease-of-flow due to temperature is the whole story. I think the key is entropy. Rubber is a thick, condensed phase material, so when the band is rapidly pulled back from its equilibrium position the molecules in the rubber take time to wiggle around and reorient themselves into an optimal configuration. Being in a non-equilibrium configuration is entropically unfavorable and thus the band has more potential energy to be converted to kinetic energy.

When the system is released, it tends back to its more entropic state, where polymers can more freely vibrate; it shrinks.

The heat makes the molecules in the rubber have more energy therefore making the rubber more elastic or "Stretchy". If the rubber cools down that extra energy is lost and the rubber returns to its original state, which reduces its elasticity which in turn reduces the velocity of the projectile.
